Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer for Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF). With it, Professor Rabi Musah from SUNY Albany and colleagues acquired a 500 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer. A NMR spectrometer measures weak signals from atomic nuclei in a sample when stimulated by light. These signals enable identification of the atoms (for example, hydrogen, carbon, and other elements) in the chemical or material under study. NMR is a powerful analytical technique used to characterize reaction products, proteins and other biological species, or unknown substances which need to be identified. Consequently, NMR spectrometers are essential to chemistry, biological and environmental research. The instrument is used to train students in the technique preparing them for their careers. The spectrometer is a resource available to other institutions in the greater Albany region including the College of St. Rose and Skidmore College.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. This instrument may impact studies synthesizing and characterizing organosulfur and organoselenium compounds, and organosulfur natural products such as plant chemical defense molecules. The instrument is used for investigating heterometallic molecular precursors for the preparation of energy-related materials. Research on carbon-rich pi-bowls, nanobelts and warped nanographene sheets advance with data from the instrument. The spectrometer is an integral tool in several projects exploring the syntheses of biologically active species. These include synthetic approaches to small-molecule peptide natural products, and the chemical synthesis of peptides, proteins and glycoproteins. Also under investigation are the synthesis of naturally modified RNA nucleosides, nucleotides and oligonucleotides and the determination of their crystal structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Intellectual Merit:

A portfolio of diverse federally- and state-funded research programs representing inorganic, organometallic, natural products, solid state, materials, bioorganic and organic synthesis areas benefitted from the acquisition of the new instrument. It supported the research programs of 10 faculty, including 6 assistant professors. All 10 faculty were major users of the equipment. During the period over which the instrument has been operational (i.e. ~2 years) and despite the slowdown in research productivity that has been imposed by the advent of the COVID-19 pandemic, there have been 30 journal articles and 30 conference and colloquia presentations that feature data generated using the spectrometer. MS and Ph.D. theses (9) were also produced. Discoveries that were made through its utilization include: development of approaches for the chemical synthesis and characterization of: creation of highly-reduced nanocarbon products; synthesis of novel RNA molecules that may have therapeutic utility; synthesis of natural products with interesting biological properties such as hitorins; development of novel synthetic approaches to biologically active cyclic peptides through native chemical ligation (NCL), generating molecules that may have importance in neurochemistry; development of cyclic heterobimetallic molecules with interesting materials properties; synthesis of novel carborane containing amino acids with anticancer properties; development of thioglycosides and photocatalyzed synthesis of acridinium molecules; creation of perchloromethylmercaptan derivatives; and development of new microporous materials with desirable semiconductivity and other ?smart? properties that can be used as sensors.

Broader impacts:

The NMR spectrometer dramatically enhanced our ability to meet one of our major educational objectives, which is to teach students how to employ modern analytical tools to solve diverse problems and answer important questions in a range of scientific disciplines. It enabled us to deliver regular hands-on training in modern NMR spectroscopy to the entire stratum of stakeholders, including undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral associates and faculty. Training in the use of NMR was integrated into our undergraduate instruction in Physical Chemistry CHM 352Z) as well as in the graduate-level Experimental Methods of Organic Structure Elucidation (CHM 472/572) courses, to best prepare our students for future employment, where there is the expectation that they would have been exposed to NMR both in terms of its practical aspects and interpretation of spectra. Our diverse constituency of trainees is 50% female, and 25% are members of underrepresented minority groups. The presence of the equipment facilitated the establishment and growth of national and international collaborations with researchers at several institutions, including the Nanyang Technological University (Singapore); the University of of Albert (Canada); the University of Oregon; Florida State University; Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research (Mainz, Germany); Zagazig University (Egypt); University of Pittsburg; NIST (Gathersburg, MD); Ube Industries Ltd. (Japan); Merck (Darmstadt, Germany); SUNY Polytechnic (Albany, NY); SUNY Environmental and Sustainable Engineering (Albany, NY); Columbia University (New York, NY); and Kinentia Biosciences (Rensselaer, NY). Approximately 100 individuals have been trained and received certification, and an additional 40 received training in data interpretation. Several individuals for whom NMR data was an important part of their graduate research have graduated and either obtained excellent positions or continued on to graduate school. Examples include: Ms. Nicola Breen and Ms. Cortney von Hahmann, undergraduate research assistants who have respectively gone on to studies at the Max Planck Institute for Kohlenforschung, and in the doctoral program of the Humboldt University of Berlin.
